comment.author: 45791749@N00
comment._content: Often those young lads fell from the yards, either into the sea or onto the deck. They hoped for the latter as that way death would be more immediate. If they fell into the sea there was zero chance of rescue. The ship sailed on.

comment.author: 30444654@N04
comment._content: best shot

comment.author: 45791749@N00
comment._content:
Imagine that ship pitching and yawing . . . . they'd experience being lifted and dropped dozens of feet: it would be hard to stay on!

A very good account of what that life was like is written in autobiographical form by Eric Newby in "The Last Grain Race."

comment.author: 28400785@N06
comment._content:
Balls o' steel. 

For better or worse, that's really the first thing that came to mind.

comment.author: 26314424@N08
comment._content: These ships were exciting but dangerous to serve on. They sorted out the men from the boys, sadly. Well taken on the rigging considering the primitive cameras available in the 1920s.

comment.author: 87667117@N00
comment._content: it was very hard to fall out of the rigging  unless somthing broke  you done somthing stupid or you got casual

comment.author: 27259664@N07
comment._content: It's the photographer I thought of when I saw this photo.  He had to be on the forward mast,  handling his camera, for this shot..

comment.author: 45791749@N00
comment._content: Cameras in the 1920s were not the compact jobs that we have now either. I guess he was hauling a big box full of plates up the mast with him. And trying to hang on.

comment.author: 34934619@N08
comment._content: I know who the original photographer is. His name was Alexander Harper Turner and he is my great-grandfather. We have a copy in our home and we also have a photocopied version from a book- I don't know the name of it at this exact moment. It also states that my great-grandfather took the picture and on our copy his name has been written on it. Thank you for all of your wonderful comments

comment.author: 34882515@N08
comment._content: He seems to have taken it from the yard of another mast. I would have died of fright before I ever got that high! Amazing shot, especially when you consider the camera equipment they had at that time. If he used both hands to hold the camera and take the shot - what was he holding on to or did he do a balancing act? Did he tie himself to the yard or mast? There is a lot of courage behind this shot!

comment.author: 87667117@N00
comment._content: think about it   the rig is designed to  climb and hold people  it looks wild  if you never worked in it , , thats why the term land lubbers is used  ,  look to the right and above of the jacks working the yard , theres a big platform   called the crosstrees  big enough  for the whole watch to stand if the    situation is to dangerours for them to go out on the yard ,  big enough fof ansell adams to set up a tripod , , then theres a working  line  called the gant , it  runs to the top of the mast or tuck ,  that  you can  pull up gear from the deck ,  whole yard arms  if need be ,  the fact that there were very few cameras  on the sailing shipps  makes it great,  the mechanics  is very ho hum , now if the  guy  had sat on the outer end  of the  yard  and  took the picture of the watch fisting canvas  at eye level that would  make me spill my beer ,

comment.author: 87667117@N00
comment._content: think about it   the rig is designed to  climb and hold people  it looks wild  if you never worked in it , , thats why the term land lubbers is used  ,  look to the right and above of the jacks working the yard , theres a big platform   called the crosstrees  big enough  for the whole watch to stand if the    situation is to dangerours for them to go out on the yard ,  big enough for ansell adams to set up a tripod , , then theres a working  line  called the gant , it  runs to the top of the mast or tuck ,  that  you can  pull up gear from the deck ,  whole yard arms  if need be ,  the fact that there were very few cameras  on the sailing ships  makes it great,  the mechanics  is very ho hum , now if the  guy  had sat on the outer end  of the  yard  and  took the picture of the watch fisting canvas  at eye level that would  make me spill my beer ,

comment.author: 73368734@N00
comment._content: Small wonder that the men who had worked on ships like this one made the most fearless of high steel workers when the skyscrapers in cities like New York were being built.  The solid, flat surface of a steel I-beam hundreds of feet above the ground would have seemed a cakewalk after working in rigging like this.

comment.author: 8357952@N06
comment._content:
To add to what daveinnola2003 said: they were safer up in the rigging with all those handholds, than down on the deck. Look at the water sloshing around there! It wouldn't have been warm water, either. 

Also bear in mind that a ship that size doesn't exactly bounce around like a dinghy: the masts alone weighed many tonnes, and changed direction in their own good  time.  Still not my idea of a fun job!

comment.author: 87667117@N00
comment._content: is any middle class  burk going to comment on the working class hero.s or does every body miss the point of the photo? , these are labourers going about their daily work , the same kind of people  that dig ditches today ,  when you sit in your air conditioned  volos at a road works  those people sweating outside of your window are the same working class people ,  dont let the majestic beauty of the sailing ships  confuse you , its fooking hard work  being a manual worker

woaw if only i shoud this one time in my life, i will be the most happy on the world, very great photo, i just want to be with the seamens in the mast...

comment.author: 45002239@N04
comment._content: daveinnola2003 has it right hauling gear aloft is no big deal to sailors of these ships.He is right too about falling, the only close calls I had aloft was from sky larking and day dreaming.I say that keeping his equipment dry and reasonably free of crud was the real trick.Dave is also correct about these workers (almost slaves) who have no choice in the matter.Is it so romantic at 03:30 with cracked ribs and bleeding hands and fingers? I'm reasonably sure she was a grain ship some times loaded with coal or guano ,these ships were large fast and under manned , crewed by poorly fed under paid young men and boys. I would not be suprised that excepting the capt., a couple of mates,cook, and the ships dog ,that those numbered on deck were no greater than those aloft.What is hard about taking photos at sea is captureing the sense of motion and the hight of the waves as this image does so well, If he had taken this at the top of her roll the photo would have less impact and drama.Pass the beer.

comment.author: 10111432@N05
comment._content: For another insight into life on the big windjammers see the film shot by Capt. Irving Johnson on the Peking (sister to the Passat mentioned above) rounding the Horn in 1929. The Peking is now a museum ship in New York City. It is still possible to sail on one like her - as a paying sail trainee - e.g. on the Russian-owner German-built Krusenshtern (ex-Padua). Also Google "The Cape Horn Road" (maybe parts 1 and 2). This is a film by one Alan Villiers.

comment._content:

comment.author: 64716589@N05
comment._content:
@ Roshi8 and national library of  NZ on the commons, I recognized this fantastic photo, from a book I have in front of me. It's called "the Golden Age of Sail" - of Australia and New Zealand.
by Captain John Noble.
 The book has many large (al b&w) photos, some with great clarity, and some with the same excitement as this. A great shot of a similar vessel being "swallowed up" by huge swells which was common place in the Southern Ocean, and another dramatic shot, of whalers being tossed from there chase boat, by the whales tail.
Absolutely GREAT pics.

comment._content: Every time I look at a photo I wonder where was the photographer standing to take his shot... this one is a real puzzle! Was this person flying or sitting on the other mast in front of this one?

comment.author: 58038062@N07
comment._content:
[http://www.flickr.com/photos/nelley2007] This photo is from the 1920's and helicopters weren't in use then and for a normal aircraft this shot would be too risky to attempt. This photo is taken from the fore top lookout position, commonly known as the crows nest.
It is a small platform high on the mast which is manned for most watches, particularly when in sight of land or other ships to avoid collisions.

comment.author: 21206714@N03
comment._content: [http://www.flickr.com/photos/58038062@N07]  Marvellous, but it sounds so dangerous! :)

comment.author: 58038062@N07
comment._content:
[http://www.flickr.com/photos/nelley2007] The life at sea then was extremely dangerous and many started as young as 11 years old.
You have faved the sailing ship Alcestis so I have put a note on the foremast which is the equivalent position from where this photo was taken.
What is more, the camera for this shot used wet plates and was most likely a 10" x 8" so therefore the best part  of 10lbs, a tripod probably weighing 20lbs and a box of wet plates would likely be another 15lbs. The platform (crows nest) was normally just big enough for 2 bodies so you can imagine the effort required with this sea running.

comment.author: 66973022@N08
comment._content: I am a photographer and use large format in difficult situations.Everything being set up before going up...no tripod, focus at infinity  hook and hoist  the camera lash it to something so you still have a paw on the rigging and the camera dosent bang around.Remove the dark slide from the film holder and click! Of course I wouldnt encourage someone without sea legs to engage in such activities but if you do you,re between ocean and big sky!
